SENT.plain: OBJECTIVES: Evidence indicates that cancer patients have increased thromboembolic risk
Given a potential role of prothrombotic clot phenotype in thrombosis, we investigated plasma fibrin clot properties in patients with digestive tract cancer (DTC)
METHODS: We studied 44 consecutive patients with DTC, including 26 subjects with colorectal cancer, versus 47 controls matched for demographics and cardiovascular risk factors

We evaluated ex vivo plasma fibrin clot permeability (K), turbidimetry (lag phase and maximum absorbance, Î”Abs), and efficiency of fibrinolysis using 3 different measures (CLT, t and maximum rate of d-dimer release from clots, d-D)
RESULTS: Patients with DTC had lower K (-11.5%, p=0.016), shorter lag phase (-5%, p=0.019), longer CLT (+17%, p<0.001) and t (+8%, p=0.031), and reduced d-D (-12%, p<0.001) compared with controls

After adjustment for potential confounders, thrombin-antithrombin (TAT) complexes were the independent predictor of CLT and t in the patients, while K was independently associated with tissue plasminogen activator but not with TAT

In high grade tumor patients (n=26) compared with the remainder (n=18), K was lower (p=0.004), and lag phase shorter (p=0.03), while CLT (p=0.012) and t (p=0.008) were longer, suggesting more profound unfavorable alterations in fibrin clots properties
CONCLUSIONS: This study is the first to show that patients with DTC tend to form less permeable fibrin clots relatively resistant to lysis
Prothrombotic clot phenotype might represent a novel prothrombotic mechanism in cancer patients
